title: Barriers to fall between university and training
text:
The barriers between university and training will be relaxed in a major reform intended to make it easier for school leavers to chose the right career and even mix university and vocational courses if that can help them get work.

The distinction between university and training courses would be blurred. SMH

A review of the way qualifications are awarded said getting through the next stage after school has to be less complex for people and the definition of courses less rigid so that a wider range of skills could be included in a degree.

Federal Education Minister Dan Tehan said "microcredentials" would be recognised to allow universities, TAFEs or training companies to offer short, highly-targeted courses to students and employers looking to fill skills gaps "without getting bogged down in red tape".

Senior secondary students would also be able to study subjects at school that count towards a vocational training qualification or university degree.

Training qualifications would be given national recognition and would be measured in terms of hours studied rather years.

The recommendations, which are contained in the review of the Australian Qualifications Framework, would give more prominence to final school exams. There was no mention of ATARs as part of the package.
description: A report recommends sweeping change to qualifications to allow a mixture of university and vocational courses.
